column4: Whenever I reboot my computer loses track of the time. This isn't limited to Ubuntu, however I'm figuring you guys might know. It isn't the mobo, though. It still happens even with a new motherboard and processor. Rebooting causes Ubuntu to go 4 hours back, and windows to go 4 hours ahead
ahh, this has to do with the system clock being set to UTC time, or not being set to UTC time
It started up suddenly though, on a previous motherboard. I have a new mobo now, and it still does it. Is this in the BIOS though? Should I set it to UTC or not to?
I can't remember what Windows does, the standard in Linux is to have the system time set to UTC and it adjusts accordingly.
I'm guessing windows doesn't do that, that is why it there is a 4 hour difference between the two OS
That would make sense, only they're both 4 hours off
For example, right now it's 10PM. Ubuntu says 6PM, and if I were to boot into windows it would say 2AM tomorrow
hmm, that is odd, 4 hours both in oposite directions?
Plus, even keeping it sync'ed with the internet (both in windows and ubuntu) gives me the same time (4 hours off both ways)
hmm, that is odd, perhaps check in the BIOS
do you have your timezones set correctly?  Perhaps in windows it is the -4 and Ubuntu is +4?
I shall, I was just hoping somebody here would know. It doesn't seem like a BIOS issue, since a new mobo didn't fix it (and no, I didn't buy a new mobo just to fix it :P)
Nope, both are set to New York
hmm, I'm not sure, more complex than I suspected. :) sorry
no problems
I rebooted, and my BIOS now has the correct time
however Ubuntu is still 4 hours off. What should I be setting it to?
hmm, I just remember that in the install or many installs it always asks if my clock is set to UTC time, and I check yes., let me see if there is somewhere to set that after install
awesome, thanks
I just told it to sync with internet, and it fixed it. We'll see upon reboot though
I don't remember hardy asking me that though, odd.
hopefully it works though. thanks for the suggestion :D
ok
no prob
